comments.commentBody: I'm not denying that racism's involved, but to say that "these clowns would never behave this low if Bush or Clinton were in the Oval Office" requires a short memory.  Remember the Gingrich Republicans who shut down the government and implied the Clintons were guilty of murder.

i liked this puzzle. TSR should have come to me right away, since I had kids who played Dungeons & Dragons. It did pop in eventually. It stands for "Tactical Studies Rules" (I just looked it up online). They are now owned by Wizards of the Coast.

I liked the bit with the 5 * answers. I got a little muddled up thinking the British mathematicians were NOBELLERS. Or somehow related to the Nobel Prize. Now off to look up AGOUTIS.

Only by separating the farmer subsidies from the Food Stamps program will we ever be able to kill the subsidies for the rich farmers.

In America today, the average farmer is a millionaire. However, they are very good at poor mouthing, despite having the lowest failure risk of any type of small business. Farmers even have a different accounting system for taxes than other small businesses. Farmers can bury huge hunks of their "cost of living" and "investments" in tax deductible "expenses," so the question, "what is their real income", is a fair one .

The sugar farmers alone cost the American public billions per year in higher prices (via import quotas). The sugar farmers have managed this sweet deal by contributing to both sides of the political aisle). Most of those billions go to less than 50 families (family/corporate farms) who have been living the high life for generations.

It is time to put our farmers on the path towards free market capitalism rather than the crony capitalism their political expenditures have secured for them.

Rebecca - look at the bill to get a feel for the size of welfare payments tp farmers. Guarantee of 90% of your five year average revenue based not on your actual revenue but on your acreage x county average production per acre x national market price for wheat, corn, etc. Those prices have beem high. This insurance product has 62% of the premium paid by tax payers, tax payer subsidy to insurers of 40¢ for every premium dollar and if the insurer has losses taxpayers make them whole.

That sounds like welfare to me. Oh, no caps on how much a wealthy soy or cotton farmer can collect. But, if all you have is 10 acres you are out of luck
...but when a third of the country is on food stamps - something isn't right...

In my highly unscientific observations, when I go my local HEB and I see the person use their "Lone Star" card for food I rarely see junk food.  I will not begrudge a person for the occasional soda or bag of chips.  The person using the card appears to be making decent purchases.  The GOP is instrumental in creating a never ending expanding circle of poverty and need.  They will actively work to defeat any legislation designed to give the working poor a wage above the subsistence level and then they bemoan the fact that more people are going on food assistance.  The GOP will then proclaim the program is rampant with fraud but deftly fail to provide hard numbers of this fraud.   The scary fact in this whole travesty is the GOP said they will draft a bill later.  The Speaker of House controls the legislative process and a bill addressing this issue is so far down on his priority list it will probably never see the light of day.   He and the rest of the GOP are probably counting the days until their month long break next month.
Excellent! This should cause a true accounting of both programs without the hostage taking each side uses to inflate the subsidies.

Severing the alliance where everyone gets more spending in exchange for giving everyone else more spending is the first small step toward fiscal sanity.

I woold have preferred to eliminate the subsidies for farmers.

Later we can decide how much we should spend for Food Stamps.

What is killing America is Dems voting for more spending for farm subsidies they think are wasteful in exchange for Republican votes for Food stamps they think are wasteful.

That's just everyone voting for waste.

As Steve of California points out, in any populist uprising, law enforcement and the military would act with overwhelming high-tech force. A better course of action is to work to vote all Conservatives out of office and to ensure fair elections. Boycott the goods and services of Conservative led corporations--which takes some research, but is well worth doing. Above all, work to demand quality education in your home district and state system. Scrutinize education candidates and demand accountability. Protect education budgets for their most essential line items. An uneducated populace is quickly enslaved, especially if they are hungry and poor.
Off with their heads!

Oh, this is so rich. The fact is, they complain about spending, but this whole new project apparently is fueled by billions of dollars in taxpayer money. I cannot believe, as a devout Eastern Orthodox Christian, that a seemingly "Christian" democratic party would do such a thing as cut off aid to the impoverished and go against the teaching of every major Christian denomination.

I'd also like to point out that the cessation of food and aid to the impoverished is why the peasants of France rose up and overthrew the French monarchy. Perhaps we should follow suit.

Them or Us, Because we don't pay them enough. They prefer the wealthy and special interest groups that pay them a lot more money. Republicans now represent money. Citizens are a nuisance that need to be elimintated. They are doing that by not working to grow the economy, taking away assitance for the poor, making the middle class poor, and taking away our rights.

The White House will probably view this as an opportunity to once again offer the GOP a deal including cuts to Social Security. I was so excited the day Obama was elected. I thought change was coming but all we've got is the worse Republican ideas given legitimacy by being enacted by a Democrat President.

Congress is a partisan body.  Historically, its corrupt and short-sighted.  One could look at its record and say due to its short election cycle its subject to the whims and tides of populist ideology. Our founding fathers in their wisdom made our House of Representatives a cesspool of ideas.  Sadly, they gave them authority to enact laws. Today they passed a Farm Bill minus support for the poor.  Will history judge them well? Honestly, few members of Congress are remembered for anything other than grave corruption or true greatness.  The former is the normal outcome.

The south would never agree to secession again since the North would become prospreous without the burden of supporting the southern states.  Sensible politicans in the non-confederate states would pass good reasonable social and economic policies.  The country would be a nice place to live for all with limited strife, dissension, and prejudice.  The South could never tolerate that...like Gobbels said "people need hate more than they need food"

That much repeated mantra of food aid deniers is way overblown. I had to rely on the food stamp program when my work ended at the beginning of the recession. I made bread from scratch, healthy traditional vegetarian dishes from other cultures (very balanced and very economical, and bought sale items.

I would compare my grocery cart to yours any day.

I tried to respond that payments went direct from clinics to individuals as inducements for patronage. Not that government programs were sending any money to program recipients After your comment and others to my posting, the discussion went off point, since it was about food stamps. My posting got deleted, likely for straying off the subject. I nevertheless smart from the application of censorship of a well-meaning, non-aggressive and certainly non-controversial attempt to add to the discussion. If Noam Chomsky were dead, he'd be smiling from his grave.

Wilson, the number of farms is quite irrelevant. Of course most farms are small. And most of those receive no subsidies. Let's look at the farms that account for the lion's share of farm revenues, and look at their share of subsidies. I think you'd find that enlightening.

I keep reading that people can use them anywhere but I've been in grocery stores and have seen the cashiers take away items that were not allowed. I don't think you can just spend the amount allocated on anything.

Also don't forget that many people working need assistance due to low paying jobs.

I read where food support was being targeted for cuts, just 20 rich Americans made as much from their 2012 investments as the entire 2012 SNAP (food assistance) budget, which serves 47 million people. "Four hundred people on the Forbes list made more from their stock market gains last year than the total amount of the food, housing, and education budgets combined."

Info: alterNet

Only a fool would countenance eliminating nutrition programs entirely.

Yes, I've seen my share of shady things: lobster houses advertising the ability to use food stamps; reports of the cards being used in Florida, Hawai'i, in casinos and in cruise ships; people using cards and then getting into new cars far nicer than mine; or my son being told how to work the system to stay on these benefits permanently.

But, for every one of those examples, I see ten needy families who, frankly, need our help. And much as I loathe seeing the system gamed from time to time, I'd rather have that than see children go hungry.

I have developed a bright line test from my years of late night shopping: send government employees to grocery stores at 11:30 PM on the last day of the month. The people waiting for midnight and their cards to kick in get to keep them, because they more likely than not really need the food. I've seen hungry people wait for clock to strike 12, and it never fails to break my heart. Everyone else gets at least a cursory audit.

I always find it ridiculous when this particular argument is used, especially when used by "small government" conservatives. They are asking for a ton of overhead to be added to the program to define what is and isn't allowed. The only reason is spite. They don't really care about the health and well-being of SNAP beneficiaries. They only care that those mongrels don't get to eat the same way they do, and be punished for being needy by only getting bread and water.

There have been spectacular Medicare/Medicare fraud cases in Florida involving hundreds of millions of dollars in the news. Saving the best for last, the current Governer was involved in a Medicare "misunderstanding" of a billion or so dollars. Go for it. Fight City Hall.

Many people are on food stamps because many people have jobs that do not pay enough to feed themselves and/or their children.

I have seen people in supermarkets use food stamps to buy food products that I consider junk, and would like to disallow food stamps for soda, candy, etc., but that is not easy.

Until we live in a better world where everyone can have a job that pays adequately, I would prefer to support food stamps than to have children in my community go hungry, and that is the choice.

Except that SNAP is a program administered by the USDA.  It would make sense to look back as to why food stamps are part of the Department of Agricultural instead of stating that welfare is a separate issue.  The government oddly put food stamps and farm policy under the same department and therefore they have a lot business being together.  Hopefully this bill could actually bring up issues about the SNAP program instead of saying that it should be pushed aside.

A person cannot afford to buy healthy food with food stamps, because food stamps don't buy much. The government subsidizes corn and wheat, so junk food is cheap, while fruits, vegetables and meat are not subsidized and are, therefore, too expensive to afford if you are on food stamps. I recommend the documentary, "A Place at the Table." It is really good movie on the food stamp program.

based on the numbers you cite, participation in the program did NOT double from 2008-2012 (the latest years shown on the chart). The fact that they did increase substantially during that period – when the nation was hemorrhaging hundreds of thousands of jobs each month – is to me, an indication that the policy helps people when they most need help and is sound public policy. In this day and age when technology has enabled us to produce more food on an acre of land than ever before in human history, there's no reason other than greed and parsimony for poor people to lack food. If we as taxpayers can afford to subsidize agribusiness, the least we can ask is that a humane baseline of food access be provided for all Americans.

I agree, but there are financial impediments to buying healthier food, especially for food stamp recipients. Food stamps are the ONLY government program that uses the USDA's "Thrifty Food Plan" to set allocations, and the Thrifty Food Plan sets grocery budgets unrealistically low (see http://frac.org/pdf/thrifty_food_plan_2012.pdf‎). It's almost impossible to create a healthy diet with the amount of money allowed.

Junk food simply costs less than fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean meats, etc. While I agree that food stamps shouldn't be used for junk food, that will be an inevitability until allocations are increased dramatically, to two or three times what they are today--a move that will be about as politically popular as repealing the Second Amendment.
Stone Soup for the 21st century.

Stu, The surplus food program was in place long before food stamps and did provide nutritious, although commoditized,  food free. It still exists in many forms and costs a tiny fraction per person compared to food stamps. While some of the foods provided do take time to prepare, others like the meat, peanut butter and cheese can be consumed without significant preparation. While taxpayers and nutritionists may consider it a win - win, retailers and   food processors hate it, as do many of the poor, who would prefer to shop in supermarkets like everyone else and dislike the stigma of its institutional labeling and packaging.

Georgia Dem:  Excuse me - "canned fruits, veggies and meats" are not part of a healthy diet. (Too much salt & sugar). Much of the rest of what you wrote strikes me as being completely unrealistic - nobody is going to "share cooking responsibilites".  As far as the tax payers are concerned it is the agro-business titans that get the welfare benefits, not the poor. I'm afraid your solution is more accurately described as being "lose, lose, lose".

I'm a Democrat and I'm ready for change. Food stamps are really corporate welfare for the retailers and convenience food processors. Go back to free commodities and cut out the middle men and cut costs. Cheese, butter,  powdered milk, dry beans, rice, oatmeal, flour and meal, canned fruits, veggies and meats. A healthy diet instead of the convenience junk foods. Every town and village has a vacant store or school building for a distribution center and add home delivery for shut-ins. Those who aren't working have the time to prepare meals from scratch. Single working parents might be hard-pressed to cook but it can be done. Teach the older children to cook. Team up with neighbors to share cooking responsibilities. Nobody goes hungry, everybody is healthier and taxpayers aren't as burdened and resentful. Win win win.

Not only am I concerned about high fees, but any fees. When there is any fee, the employees are not being paid, on the spot, what they are owed. The employment agreement isn't to work for a certain amount per hour, net of fees, it's to work for a certain amount per hour, cash.

The employer is already advantaged by the float of the week's work being done prior to payment being tendered, why should the employee then be disadvantaged by the trouble and cost of converting his "just like cash" scrip, because that's what these cards really are - scrip that generally trades at a discount to its stated cash value.

If it's not money, the employee hasn't really been paid, he's been scammed. Why not simply pay him in shares of a Ponzi scheme? Then the employers can really get over on their employees, big time!

This disgrace of a political party has taken the spirit of self righteousness and downright meanness to new depths. We were once a country that solved problems, built things up and planned for the next generation. Is that Lady Liberty crying or looking, like me, for a place to hide rather than witness the systematic dismantling of our social contract? I cry for the end of fairness in public policy and the arrogance of elected representatives whose mission is to seek victory by causing failure. There are many many suffering people who are  watching this charade and the grapes of wrath are growing heavy.
